title: Transport in London
data: London Overground metro service across London
Essex Thameside - local and regional/commuter services from Fenchurch Street to East London and South Essex
London to Aylesbury Line - local and regional/commuter services from Marylebone to North West London , Buckinghamshire
Regional services from St Pancras to Corby

Thameslink Southern & Great Northern franchise - operate under the Gatwick Express , Great Northern , Southern , and Thameslink brands from King 's Cross , Moorgate , Blackfriars , London Bridge and Victoria to North London , South London , Hertfordshire , Cambridgeshire , Bedfordshire , Kent and Sussex , also operate cross city services via the Thameslink route
Greater Western franchise - local and regional/commuter services from Paddington to West London and the Thames Valley
East Anglia franchise - local and regional/commuter services from Liverpool Street to Essex , Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire , also operate the Stansted Express
Non-stop service from Paddington to Heathrow Airport
Local and regional/commuter services from Euston to Hertfordshire , Buckinghamshire and Northamptonshire , Warwickshire , Staffordshire and Birmingham
South Western franchise - local services from Waterloo to South West London and regional/commuter services to Surrey , Hampshire , Dorset & Berkshire
South Eastern franchise - local metro services across South East London and commuter and regional services from Victoria , Charing Cross , Cannon Street , Blackfriars and St Pancras to Kent
Local and commuter services from Liverpool Street to Gidea Park and Shenfield , plus Paddington to Hayes & Harlington and Heathrow Terminal 4 , will operate the Elizabeth line from 2019
section_text: Thameslink trains run a cross London route through Central London Unlike the Underground , which is a single system owned and operated by Transport for London , commuter railways in London are run by a number of separate train operating companies ( TOCs ) . This results from the privatisation of British Rail in the 1990s which split the former state railway operator British Rail into a number of smaller franchises in order to increase competition and allow railways to operate in a free market Among the rail firms operating passenger services in London , a number are owned by foreign companies or by state-owned railways of other European countries . [ 21 ] [ 22 ] [ 23 ] London Overground is contracted in a different way to other franchises in that it is operated by a private company under contract to Transport for London . Heathrow Express is also unusual in that it is not officially part of the National Rail franchising system
